item: Indicate Mendelian randomization (MR) as the study's design in the title and/or the abstract if that is a main purpose of the study

Explain the scientific background and rationale for the reported study. What is the exposure? Is a potential causal relationship between exposure and outcome plausible? Justify why MR is a helpful method to address the study question
State specific objectives clearly, including pre-specified causal hypotheses (if any). State that MR is a method that, under specific assumptions, intends to estimate causal effects
Present data sources of the study early in the article
Present 2. Methods of the study in the article
Present 3. Exposures of the study in the article
Present 4. Outcomes of the study in the article
including a table listing sources of data for all phases of the study
[Setting] For each data source, describe its study design
[Setting] For each data source, describe its underlying population
[Setting] For each data source,  describe its locations
[Setting] For each data source, describe relevant dates, including periods of recruitment
[Setting] For each data source, describe its exposure
[Setting] For each data source, describe how the follow-up process was conducted
[Setting] For each data source, describe the data collection process
[Paricipants] For each data source, give the eligibility criteria, and the sources and methods of selection of participants
[Paricipants] For each data source, report the sample size
[Paricipants] For each data source, report whether any power or sample size calculations were carried out prior to the main analysis
[Paricipants] For each data source, describe measurement of genetic variants
[Paricipants] For each data source,  describe quality control of genetic variants
[Paricipants] For each data source, describe  selection of genetic variants
Describe methods of assessment and diagnostic criteria for each exposure
Describe methods of assessment and diagnostic criteria for each outcome
Describe methods of assessment and diagnostic criteria for other relevant variables
Provide details of ethics committee approval and participant informed consent, if relevant
Explicitly state the relevance assumption of IV
Explicitly state the independence assumption of IV
Explicitly state the exclusion assumption of IV
State assumptions for any additional or sensitivity analysis
Describe how quantitative variables were handled in the analyses (i.e., scale, units, model)
Describe how genetic variants were handled in the analyses and, if applicable, how their weights were selected
note: Example:selection thresholds, LD pruning, palindromic SNP handling, allele score

item: Describe the MR estimator (e.g. two-stage least squares, Wald ratio) and related statistics.
Detail the included covariates
in case of two-sample MR, whether the same covariate set was used for adjustment in the two samples
Explain how missing data were addressed
If applicable, indicate how multiple testing was addressed
Describe any methods or prior knowledge used to assess the relevance assumption of IV
Describe any methods or prior knowledge used to assess the independence  assumption of IV
Describe any methods or prior knowledge used to assess the exclusion assumption of IV
Describe any methods or prior knowledge used to assess the assumptions for any additional analysis or sensitivity analysis
Describe any sensitivity analyses or additional analyses performed
note: Eample: comparison of effect estimates from different approaches, independent replication, bias analytic techniques, validation of instruments, simulations

item: Name statistical software and package(s), including version and settings used
note: All versions for software packages must be described

item: State whether the study protocol and details were pre-registered (as well as when and where)
Report the numbers of individuals at each stage of included studies and reasons for exclusion. Consider use of a flow diagram
Report summary statistics for phenotypic exposure(s), outcome(s), and other relevant variables (e.g. means, SDs, proportions)
If the data sources include meta-analyses of previous studies, provide the assessments of heterogeneity across these studies
note: Example: I2 statistic, Q statistic, or between-study variance

item: For two-sample MR: Provide justification of the similarity of the genetic variant-exposure associations between the exposure and outcome samples
For two-sample MR: Provide information on the number of individuals who overlap between the exposure and outcome studies
Report the associations between genetic variant and exposure, and between genetic variant and outcome, preferably on an interpretable scale

Report MR estimates of the relationship between exposure and outcome, and the measures of uncertainty from the MR analysis, on an interpretable scale, such as odds ratio or relative risk per SD difference
Describe whether translating estimates of relative risk into absolute risk is conducted
Consider plots to visualize results (e.g. forest plot, scatterplot of associations between genetic variants and outcome versus between genetic variants and exposure)
Report results of the assessment of the relevance assumption
Report results of the assessment of the independence assumption
Report results of the assessment of the exclusion assumption
Report results of the assessment of the any additional assumption, if relevant
Report any additional statistics
note: Example: assessments of heterogeneity across genetic variants, such as I2, Q statistic or E-value

item: Report results from any sensitivity analyses to assess the robustness of the main results to violations of the assumptions
Report results from other sensitivity analyses or additional analyses
Report any assessment of direction of causal relationship (e.g., bidirectional MR)
Report and compare with estimates from non-MR analyses
Consider additional plots to visualize results (e.g., leave-one-out analyses)
Summarize key results with reference to study objectives
Limitation: discuss the validity of the IV assumptions
Limitation: discuss other sources of potential bias and imprecision
Limitation: discuss both direction and magnitude of any potential bias and any efforts to address them
Meaning: Give a cautious overall interpretation of results in the context of their limitations and in comparison with other studies
Mechanism: Discuss underlying biological mechanisms that could drive a potential causal relationship between the investigated exposure and the outcome
Mechanism: Discuss whether the gene-environment equivalence assumption is reasonable
Mechanism: Clarifying that IV estimates may provide causal effects only under certain assumptions
Clinical relevance: Discuss whether the results have clinical or public policy relevance, and to what extent they inform effect sizes of possible interventions
Discuss the generalizability of the study results to other populations
Discuss the generalizability of the study results across other exposure periods/timings
Discuss the generalizability of the study results across other levels of exposure
Describe sources of funding in the present study
Describe  the role of funders in the present study
If applicable, describe sources of funding for the databases or studies on which the present study is based
Provide the data used to perform all analyses or report where and how the data can be accessed, and reference these sources in the article
Provide the statistical code needed to reproduce the results in the article, or report whether the code is publicly accessible and if so, where
